title: 110_s2304
content: The Act may be cited as the "Mentally Ill Offender Treatment and Crime Reduction Reauthorization and Improvement Act of 2008". The table of contents for this Act is provided. The "Mentally Ill Offender Treatment and Crime Reduction Reauthorization and Improvement Act of 2008" includes provisions for reauthorizing collaboration program grants, improving law enforcement response to mentally ill offenders, and examining the prevalence of mentally ill offenders in the criminal justice system. Congress finds that communities struggle to address the high numbers of mentally ill individuals in the criminal justice system, with a significant percentage of incarcerated individuals suffering from mental illnesses. Los Angeles County Jail and New York's Rikers Island jail hold more mentally ill individuals than some of the largest psychiatric facilities in the United States. The reauthorization of the Adult and Juvenile Collaboration Program Grants under the "Mentally Ill Offender Treatment and Crime Reduction Reauthorization and Improvement Act of 2008" includes allocating $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2009 to 2014. This aims to improve law enforcement response to mentally ill offenders and address the high prevalence of mental illness among incarcerated individuals. The reauthorization of the Adult and Juvenile Collaboration Program Grants includes allocating funds for administrative expenses of the Attorney General not exceeding 3% for fiscal year 2009 and subsequent years. The Attorney General has priority in awarding funds under this program. The Attorney General prioritizes applications for funds that promote effective strategies for mentally ill offenders, especially females, and expand mental health courts. Strong commitment to public health and safety is required for funding consideration. The Attorney General is authorized to make grants for treatment services for adults or juveniles during incarceration or detention, with support from both the Attorney General and the Secretary. Law Enforcement Response to Mentally Ill Offenders Improvement Grants are available under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. The Attorney General can make grants for training programs, specialized receiving centers, and improved technology to assist law enforcement personnel in responding to incidents involving individuals with mental illnesses. The curr_chunk provides funding for training programs, cooperative efforts between justice and mental health agencies, and campus security personnel training to improve responses to mentally ill offenders. The Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance will develop training models. The Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance will develop training models for law enforcement personnel to identify and respond to incidents involving individuals with mental illnesses, including suicide prevention. The Federal share of funds for a program funded by a grant may not exceed 50 percent of the costs. The Attorney General will examine and report on mental illness and the criminal justice system, with a focus on specific areas encouraged by Congress. The Attorney General will specifically examine the rate of serious mental illnesses in various populations involved in the criminal justice system and the percentage of individuals receiving disability benefits. A report to Congress is due within 36 months of the Act's enactment. The Attorney General will submit a report to Congress within 36 months of the Act's enactment, defining "serious mental illness" as a diagnosable disorder meeting specific criteria. The authorization of appropriations for this section is $2,000,000 for 2009. This section does not cover V codes, substance use disorders, or developmental disorders unless they cooccur with another disorder and cause significant functional impairment.
